<@U053PPGDC>  Because i want to track the salesperson. Any solution about service stopped when app minimize or screen lock.

<@U25CTHVN0> sounds like your service is bound to your activity so when your activity stops your service is stopping. Do a background service instead and use a foreground notification to ensure it stays alive (as best as you can) and use START_STICKY.
As for tracking constantly, as <@U053PPGDC> notes: this will kill the battery life if you do it constantly.
you could use something like this to find the middle ground for you though <https://code.google.com/archive/p/little-fluffy-location-library/>
Thats a handy one
How you find this stuff? :smile:
when was it last updated? iirc it’s ultra old
what’s the discussion?
<@U055GGAHS>  Thanks for reply.  I used in START_STICKY in onstartcommand itself. I have created Service also by extending service class and start it using startservice(Intent)
yes and it sounds like you used a binder to talk to it
<@U053PPGDC> Thanks for your reply   :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U055GGAHS> Frankly speaking, I am beginner so using background service for the first time.
that library I linked you does it for you, I would recommend that then.
You are going to destroy the battery life of the device if you don’t set it up right
<@U055GGAHS>  Thanks  Will try to use it. :slightly_smiling_face:

so i think all the work you do should be depend on the requirements.. but if you really wants to get location update every 10sec then you have to make sure that you app dont drain the battery..
as now in android it will show which app drain the battery most..

<@U061HDV96> I have a python program which produces some result taking a particular input. So I want to make a RESTful API for that so people can use the API over Internet inputting some parameters and getting the result back
Quick question
is this construct ever a good idea?
`List<Map<Thing, OtherThing>>`
I've recently done this `Map<Thing, List<SomethingElse>>`

*gradle question* What is `-D` on gradle? I know that there `-s -PmyParam="myValue"` for parameters but… whats the idea of the -D? 
They show it here <https://plugins.gradle.org/plugin/com.gradle.build-scan>
I cant find docs in <https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/tutorial_gradle_command_line.html>
Set system property
same as maven
-P is project property
<https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/gradle_command_line.html>
yeah but question is about `-D`
they use `-Dscan`
set a system property called `scan`
what’s the big deal?
nothing… just didnt know that
<@U0MJLRK96> allow me to explain in detail
the -D flag basically sets a temporary system var
something like what you’d have in .bashrc
or PATH on windows
some tools use it extensively as the choice location for where to get data
maven for example, when you want to skip tests
`mvn package -Dskip.tests`
So it looks like your gradle plugin is pretty much just doing the same thing
at runtime it checks path for `scan` variable, if it’s there it does it’s job
:metal: wow thanks
got it
<@U08GFT5V5> :taco:
:partyparrot:
Trying to do some unit testing, are testing database login, recieve values etc tests needed ?
in unit testing you’d abstract all that and test “units” of your app’s logic
testing db calls etc would be testing the db and that’s db developers’ job
but what if the developer is google, then I don’t need to ? :smile:
I’m working with firebase
as I said - don’t test the logic you don’t own
best practice would be to wrap it, abstract it with classes you can control, something that better relates to your business logic, and unit test that - so that it doesn’t actually hit the db
hey guys, not strictly a development question, but we’ve recently launched an upgrade to an app we have in the play store
the thing is, even after a month, we still ~50% of our userbase using the old version
I know google play doesn’t necessarily update everything immediately, but this number seems strange
How long has the update been out?
a month or so

Further, there really isn’t much that can be done other than to notify existing users about the update. For future updates, you can implement something like <https://github.com/javiersantos/AppUpdater>

attachments.title: javiersantos/AppUpdater
attachments.text: AppUpdater - A library that checks for your apps' updates on Google Play, GitHub, Amazon, F-Droid or your own server. API 8+ required.

text: but it could very well be a google play console bug, because it does show that the old version starts to decline on launch day
but it is not replaced by the new version
What do your analytics tell you about active users and which version they are using?

I have an app where Google Play says 35% of my users have a version of the app from 10 iterations ago (~1 year old) but my analytics tell me that my active users are all using the current version or one version prior.
Actually, just checked my play store stats and those 35% are still on a version that I released *August 8th, 2014*
right, yeah, I think it’s just that google play might still be counting inactive phones that installed the app somewhere in the past
nothing to worry about then
thanks :slightly_smiling_face:
Yup, that’s why it is important to have some sort of analytics since the Play Store stats are not accurate in my experience.
agree - answers by crashlytics gives different data
yeah, we do have that, It’s just that we migrated from GA to crashlytics/answers between versions, so it’s not directly comparable
but looking at the count of both you seem to be correct
very few hits on the old GA property
I have both Answers + GA in this app and have different results. So not sure who to trust.
I have a wrapper Analytics class that fires off the same events to both services.
